revision.text:
{{Good Article}} {{Use dmy dates|date=May 2011}} {{Use Australian English|date=May 2011}} {{Infobox military unit |unit_name=2nd Commando Regiment |image=[[Image:AUS2CDO.jpg|200px]] |caption=Badge of the 2nd Commando Regiment |country=Australia |allegiance= |type=[[Special Forces]] |branch=[[Australian Army]] |dates=19 June 2009 – Present |specialization=[[Special operations]]
Domestic [[counter-terrorism]] |command_structure=[[Special Operations Command (Australia)|Special Operations Command]] |size=One [[regiment]] * Four commando companies * Three supporting companies |current_commander= |garrison=[[Holsworthy Barracks]], [[Sydney]]{{cite web |title=Army Bases|url=http://www.defencejobs.gov.au/army/about-the-army/army-bases/|website=Defence Jobs|date=2014|publisher=Defence Force Recruiting|accessdate=3 May 2015}} |ceremonial_chief= |ceremonial_chief_label= |nickname= |motto="''Foras Admonitio''"
(Without Warning){{cite web |title= 2nd Commando Regiment |publisher=Australian Army |date=1 February 2012 |url=http://www.army.gov.au/Who-we-are/Divisions-and-Brigades/Special-Operations-Command/2nd-Commando-Regiment|archiveurl=http://webarchive.nla.gov.au/gov/20120316210534/http://www.army.gov.au/Who-we-are/Divisions-and-Brigades/Special-Operations-Command/2nd-Commando-Regiment |accessdate=29 June 2012|archivedate=17 March 2012 |location=Canberra}} |colors= |identification_symbol=[[File:2nd Commando Regiment Unit Colour Patch.png|150px]] |identification_symbol_label=Unit Colour Patch |identification_symbol_2=2 CDO REGT |identification_symbol_2_label=Abbreviation |march= |mascot= |battles= '''[[East Timor]]''' *[[INTERFET]] *[[United Nations Transitional Administration in East Timor]] *[[Operation Astute]] '''[[War in Afghanistan (2001–present)|War in Afghanistan]]''' *[[Operation Slipper]] *[[Shah Wali Kot Offensive]] '''[[2003 Iraq War]]''' *[[Operation Falconer]] *[[Operation Catalyst]] '''[[2014 military intervention against ISIL|Military intervention against ISIL]]''' *[[Operation Okra]] |decorations=[[Unit Citation for Gallantry]]{{cite web |url=http://www.gg.gov.au/governorgeneral/speech.php?id=292 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091004112926/http://www.gg.gov.au/governorgeneral/speech.php?id=292 |title=Address by His Excellency Major General Michael Jeffery on the Occasion of Presentation of the Unit Citation for Gallantry to 4RAR (Commando) |publisher=Governor General of Australia |archivedate=4 October 2009 |accessdate=30 June 2013}}
[[Meritorious Unit Citation]]{{cite web|url=http://www.4rarassociationsaustralia.com/4rarmuc.html|title=Special Operations Task Group (Task Force 637) Meritorious Unit Citation|year=2007|publisher=4RAR Association|accessdate=14 June 2010}} |anniversaries= }} The '''2nd Commando Regiment''' is a [[special forces]] unit of the [[Australian Army]], and is part of [[Special Operations Command (Australia)|Special Operations Command]]. The regiment was established on 19 June 2009 when the [[4th Battalion, Royal Australian Regiment|4th Battalion, Royal Australian Regiment (Commando)]] was renamed. It is based at [[Holsworthy Barracks|Holsworthy]], [[New South Wales]]. The 2nd Commando Regiment often trains and deploys with the [[Special Air Service Regiment]], is highly regarded by coalition special operation forces abroad, and has been involved in operations in [[Operation Astute|East Timor]], [[Operation Catalyst|Iraq]] and [[Operation Slipper|Afghanistan]], where it was used in a direct action warfighting role. It has also been involved in a number of domestic security operations including the [[2006 Commonwealth Games]] and the [[2014 G-20 Brisbane summit|2014 G20 Leaders Summit]]. ==Role== Part of [[Special Operations Command (Australia)|Special Operations Command]] (SOCOMD),{{sfn|McPhedran|2005|p=338}} the 2nd Commando Regiment is one of three combat-capable units within SOCOMD{{sfn|AAP|2009|}} and operates in conjunction with other SOCOMD units, services and interagency organisations in joint and combined operations.{{cite web|title=Roles of the 2nd Commando Regiment|url=http://2commando.gov.au/about/our-roles|website=2nd Commando Regiment|publisher=Department of Defence|accessdate=20 August 2016}} The role of the regiment is to conduct large scale offensive, support and recovery operations beyond the scope and capability of other Australian Defence Force (ADF) units.{{cite web|title=History – 4th Battalion, Royal Australian Regiment|url=http://www.4rarassociationsaustralia.com/history.html|website=4 RAR Associations of Australia|accessdate=20 August 2016}} Army doctrine specifies that the role of commando units is to "span the gap between conventional infantry operations and unconventional operations", focusing on [[Advanced Force Operations|advance force operations]] and [[Direct action (military)|direct action]] missions.{{cite news|title=Commando (Land Warfare Doctrine 3-3-11 Employment of Special Operations, 2005)|url=http://armynews.realviewdigital.com/?iid=5264&xml=defencenews_army.xml|accessdate=30 August 2016|work=Army: The Soldiers' Newspaper|edition=1174|date=6 September 2007|pages=25|publisher=Department of Defence|location=Canberra|issn=0729-5685}} Formed to complement the [[Special Air Service Regiment]] (SASR), according to Blaxland the regiment is designed to be a "self-contained flexible and rapidly deployable force" and is structured for both special operations and domestic [[counter-terrorism]].{{sfn|Blaxland|2014|p=175}} In its domestic counter-terrorism role it provides the [[Tactical Assault Group|Tactical Assault Group (East)]] to respond to high-risk incidents on the eastern coast of Australia beyond the capability of state/territory and federal [[Police tactical group|Police Tactical Groups]] to respond to.{{sfn|Davies|Jennings|Scheer|2014|p=10}} The regiment maintains a high readiness element which encompasses the parachute company group role that the [[3rd Battalion, Royal Australian Regiment]] (3 RAR) had maintained prior to being reroled as a light infantry battalion.{{cite news|url=http://www.defence.gov.au/news/armynews/editions/1268/1268.pdf|title=Transfer of parachute capability announced|newspaper=Army: The Soldiers' Newspaper|edition=1268|date=29 September 2011|publisher=Department of Defence|location=Canberra|p=3|issn=0729-5685|ref=harv}}{{sfn|Scanlan|2012|pp=37–54}} ==History== ===Formation=== In 1995, as part of an expansion of the number of [[Australian Army]] infantry battalions, the [[2nd/4th Battalion, Royal Australian Regiment]]—then operating as a standard light infantry battalion—was delinked into separate battalions which resumed their original identities as the [[2nd Battalion, Royal Australian Regiment|2nd]] and [[4th Battalion, Royal Australian Regiment|4th Battalions]].{{sfn|Horner|2008|p=295}} The decision was then taken that the 4th Battalion would become a Regular Army [[commando]] unit and on 1 February 1997 the unit was renamed to 4th Battalion, Royal Australian Regiment (Commando) (4 RAR Cdo). The unit would be structured for both conventional operations and domestic counter-terrorism, with an initial establishment of a battalion headquarters, Tactical Assault Group, two commando companies, logistic support company, logistic support company, operational support company and a signal squadron.{{sfn|Horner|2008|p=329}} Regular serving members were given the opportunity to undertake special forces training provided by the Commando Training Wing of the Reserve [[1st Commando Regiment (Australia)|1st Commando Regiment]], or elect to be posted to a conventional forces unit.{{sfn|Collins|2005|pp=244–245}} No General Reserve positions existed in the new structure, and reserve members discharged or posted to reserve units.{{cite web|url=http://2commando.gov.au/about/unit-history|title=Unit History|date=2013|website=2nd Commando Regiment|publisher=Department of Defence|accessdate=9 September 2014}} It was planned that 4 RAR (Cdo) would eventually take over the SASR counter terrorist role.{{sfn|Horner|Thomas|2009|pp=301}} The initial years were busy with the unit creating a structure and recruiting members suitable for commando training, while conducting sub-unit and unit training activities.{{cite web|title=4RAR History 1995–2000|url=http://webarchive.nla.gov.au/gov/20011101180205/http://www.defence.gov.au/army/4rar/history6.html|website=Australian Army|date=2 November 2001}} B Company was raised in 1997, followed by C Company in 1999, both of which took 24 months to reach full maturity. A small team from 4 RAR (Cdo) deployed to [[East Timor]] as part of the [[International Force for East Timor]] (INTERFET) in September 1999 providing close personal protection for the media and also as interpreters in the initial months.{{cite web|title=Op WARDEN|url=http://2commando.gov.au/about/past-and-current-operations/28-op-warden|website=2nd Commando Regiment|publisher=Department of Defence|accessdate=17 August 2016}} In 2000, elements were involved in the evacuation of Australian nationals from the Solomon Islands in June.{{cite web|title=Op PLUMBOMB|url=http://2commando.gov.au/about/past-and-current-operations/45-op-plumbomb|website=2nd Commando Regiment|publisher=Department of Defence|accessdate=17 August 2016}} While later that year, 4 RAR (Cdo) assisted with counter-terrorism at the [[Sydney Olympic Games]] as part of Joint Task Force 114, with C Company on standby as a response force such as providing a cordon around an incident site in support of the SASR.{{sfn|Campbell|2001|pp=1}}{{sfn|Horner|Thomas|2009|pp=330}} In 2000, it was decided that the counter terrorist role should remain with the SASR.{{sfn|Horner|Thomas|2009|pp=301}} A period of rapid capability development, equipment acquisition and training subsequently followed. The unit that was developed as a result is highly regarded by coalition special operation forces abroad, and has conducted operations in East Timor, Iraq and Afghanistan. It has also been awarded a number of citations for bravery and meritorious service. On 19 June 2009, the battalion was renamed the 2nd Commando Regiment.{{cite news|last1=Brooke|first1=Michael|title=A special moment in unit history|url=http://www.defence.gov.au/news/armynews/editions/1216/1216.pdf|accessdate=10 July 2016|work=Army: The Soldiers' Newspaper|edition=1216|date=9 July 2009|publisher=Department of Defence|location=Canberra|issn=0729-5685}} Regardless, the name 4 RAR remains on the Army's [[order of battle]] and its history, colours and traditions have been preserved, ready to be re-raised as a regular infantry battalion in the future if required. All awards and battle honours received during the time as 4 RAR (Cdo) were passed onto the 2nd Commando Regiment, while those awarded before the transformation to a commando battalion were retained by 4 RAR.{{cite press release|title=New Name for Sydney Commandos|publisher=Department of Defence|date=19 June 2009|url=http://www.defence.gov.au/media/DepartmentalTpl.cfm?CurrentId=9192|accessdate=16 September 2015}} ===East Timor=== The 2nd Commando Regiment, then known as 4 RAR (Cdo), was deployed as a part of the [[United Nations Transitional Administration in East Timor]] (UNTAET) in 2001. When notified to replace 1 RAR in [[East Timor]], 4 RAR had not long previously been raised as a commando battalion, developing special forces capabilities to supplement those of the SASR. With the commitment to East Timor continuing, however, 4 RAR was re-roled as a light infantry battalion for deployment to East Timor as AUSBATT IV. This involved reorganising from the existing two commando-companies structure to a light infantry battalion with four companies and a growth in the unit from 220 to 670 personnel.{{sfn|Campbell|2001|pp=1}} This saw B and C Company remain commando-qualified. A Company was formed in June 2000 followed by D Company in November both filled with Regular infantry soldiers posted in to the unit.{{sfn|Campbell|2001|pp=1}} The battalion took official control over [[Area of operations|Area of Operations]] (AO) Matilda in the northern border region on 25 April under the command of Lieutenant Colonel Jeff Sengelman.{{sfn|Campbell|2001|pp=11}}{{sfn|Horner|2008|pp=315–317}} During its time deployed as a part of UNTAET, the battalion established a security partnership with the East Timorese, focusing strongly on languages and maintaining the relationships previous Australian battalions had established, as well as transferring new technologies to the local security forces. This "intelligence-led" but "people-focused" approach saw the battalion group conduct the majority of its operations in close proximity to the Tactical Coordination Line (TCL) on the border with Indonesian [[West Timor]]. The battalion saw few contacts while in East Timor. These included a TCL violation on 5 May 2001 which was intercepted by a section from D Company, an outbreak of violence involving a grenade attack by militia members at the Maubasa markets on 29 May which resulted in several people killed and about 50 wounded, and shallow cross-border militia raids in June, including an attack on a section patrol from A Company. The battalion was withdrawn and replaced in October 2001.{{sfn|Campbell|2001|pp=11–24}}{{sfn|Horner|2008|pp=316–318}} ===Expansion and domestic security=== [[File:Soldiers from the Australian Army 2nd Commando Regiment fast rope from an S-70A-9 Black Hawk from the Australian Army 171st Aviation Squadron during exercise Talisman Sabre 2015.jpg|thumb|Commandos fast rope from a [[171st Aviation Squadron (Australia)|171st Aviation Squadron]] Blackhawk helicopter during Exercise Talisman Sabre 2015]] Following the battalion's return from East Timor it was again restructured to resume its role as a two-company commando battalion.{{sfn|Horner|2008|p=329}} However, in 2001 the Australian Government directed the permanent establishment of a second TAG to be based on the east coast of Australia. A Company was subsequently raised as a commando company in 2002. Following the creation of SOCOMD in 2002 and the [[2002 Bali bombings|Bali bombings]] in October that year, further resources became available.{{sfn|Blaxland|2014|p=328}} The battalion was subsequently involved in security operations for the [[Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting]] (CHOGM) in Queensland in 2002. Elements of the battalion were also involved in the boarding of a North Korean freighter, the [[Pong Su|MV ''Pong Su'']]—which was suspected of drug smuggling—off [[Newcastle, New South Wales|Newcastle]] on 20 April 2003.{{sfn|Mickelburough|2003|p=1}}{{sfn|Blaxland|2014|p=287}}{{refn|Commanded by CO 4 RAR (Cdo), the operation involved members of TAG (West), TAG (East) and the Incident Response Regiment.{{sfn|Blaxland|2014|p=287}}|group=Note}} In 2005, a fourth commando company was subsequently raised, with D Company being formed. Later, the battalion was tasked with supporting the security arrangements for the [[2006 Commonwealth Games]] in Melbourne.{{sfn|Blaxland|2014|p=311}} In 2014, elements of the regiment were deployed to Brisbane to protect the [[2014 G-20 Brisbane summit|G20 Leaders Summit]] held in the city on 15 and 16 November.{{cite web|title=ADF support G20 Leaders Summit|url=http://www.army.gov.au/Our-work/News-and-media/ADF-support-G20-Leaders-Summit|publisher=Australian Army|accessdate=22 November 2014}} ===Iraq=== The battalion provided a commando force element as part of the Australian contribution to the 2003 invasion of Iraq, known as [[Operation Falconer]]. A reinforced commando platoon formed an element of the Australian Special Forces Task Group (SFTG), which also included 1 Squadron, SASR, a troop from the [[Incident Response Regiment]], and three [[CH-47 Chinook]] helicopters from the [[5th Aviation Regiment (Australia)|5th Aviation Regiment]]. The commandos formed the "[[Quick reaction force|quick reaction]]" element for the task group. The SFTG operated in western Iraq where it was successful in securing its area of operations, including the huge [[Al Asad Air Base]].{{sfn|McPhedran|2005|pp=250–325}}{{sfn|Department of Defence|2004|pp=21–26}} After the invasion was complete, the 40-man commando element provided security to humanitarian assistance missions and other security operations, later providing close protection for Australian officials in [[Baghdad]] as part of [[Operation Catalyst]].{{sfn|Horner|2008|pp=329–330}} In 2004, claims appeared in the media that Australian special forces were involved in counter-insurgency operations inside Iraq, although this was denied by the government.{{sfn|Toohey|2004|}}{{cite press release|title=Financial Review Wrong on Special Forces Allegations|publisher=Department of Defence|date=28 August 2004|url=http://www.defence.gov.au/media/DepartmentalTpl.cfm?CurrentId=4198|archiveurl=http://webarchive.nla.gov.au/gov/20140804003917/http://www.defence.gov.au/media/DepartmentalTpl.cfm?CurrentId=4198|accessdate=22 November 2014|archivedate=4 August 2014}} The last commando element was withdrawn in 2006.{{cite web|url=http://www.4rarassociationsaustralia.com/world-template.html|title=RAR global operations|year=2007|publisher=4RAR Association|accessdate=14 June 2010}} ===Timor Leste=== Later, in May 2006 a commando company group was deployed to [[Timor Leste]] as part of [[Operation Astute]], after relations between the East Timorese government and military forces broke down.{{sfn|Farrell|2006|p=34}} The commandos operated alongside the SASR as part of the Special Forces Component{{sfn|Blaxland|2014|p=201}} and were tasked with advanced force operations in preparation for the arrival of follow-on forces, focusing on [[Presidente Nicolau Lobato International Airport|Dili Airport]]. In March 2007, the commandos, along with elements of the SASR, took part in the [[Battle of Same]] during which five rebels were killed during an unsuccessful attempt to apprehend the rebel leader, [[Alfredo Reinado]]. After the battle, the commandos and SASR elements were withdrawn at the request of the East Timorese government in order to start negotiations with the rebels.{{sfn|Australian & NZ Defender Magazine|2007|pp=22–26}} ===Afghanistan=== [[File:580164 2nd Commando Regiment Afghanistan 2012 walking to US Army Chinook.jpg|thumb|right|Commandos walking with Afghan National Army to a waiting U.S. Army Chinook helicopter in 2012]] Meanwhile, in August 2005 an Australian Special Forces Task Group (SFTG) was deployed to [[Afghanistan]] as part of [[Operation Slipper]], operating in the southern province of [[Uruzgan Province|Uruzgan]]. The SFTG, based on similar structure deployed during Operation Falconer, was made up of elements from the SASR, a commando company and a troop from the Incident Response Regiment. Two CH-47 Chinook helicopters from the 5th Aviation Regiment were deployed to Afghanistan in March 2006 to support the SFTG.{{sfn|Dennis et al|2008|p=9}} A forward operating base was subsequently established at [[Tarin Kowt]].{{sfn|Horner|2008|p=337}} During this deployment the Commandos were involved in [[Operation Perth]] which resulted in the death of over 150 Taliban and al-Qaeda fighters in nine days of fierce fighting in the Chora district of Uruzgan Province.{{sfn|The Age|2010|}} The SFTG was withdrawn from Afghanistan in September 2006 and replaced by a Reconstruction Taskforce made up of engineers and conventional infantry.{{sfn|Dennis et al|2008|p=9}} During this period the task group was on patrol for 306 days and involved in 139 contacts and sustained 11 soldiers wounded.{{sfn|Walters|2006|p=11}}{{sfn|Horner|2008|p=338}} A 300-strong Special Operations Task Group (SOTG) was subsequently deployed to support the Reconstruction Taskforce in April 2007, including a commando company group, elements of the SASR, and an integral combat service support team.{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/asia-pacific/6540135.stm |title=Australia to double Afghan force |publisher=[[bbc.co.uk]] |date=10 April 2007 |accessdate=12 April 2007}}{{cite web |title= Global Operations – Department of Defence |publisher=Australian Department of Defence |date= |url=http://www.defence.gov.au/opEx/global/index.htm |accessdate=15 April 2009 | archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090410024243/http://www.defence.gov.au/opex/global/index.htm| archivedate=10 April 2009|deadurl= no}} In the latter part of 2008 the commando company conducted a disruption operation in Helmand province as part of [[Operation Eagle's Summit]], which was a major coalition operation conducted in support of the transport and installation of an additional turbine for the [[Kajaki Dam]] hydroelectric facility.{{sfn|Roxburgh|2010|p=27}} In March and April 2009, SOTG killed 80 Taliban fighters in a major four-week operation in [[Helmand Province]], without suffering any casualties.{{sfn|Brown|2009|}} Further operations undertaken include the Battle of Gizab in April 2010, and the [[Shah Wali Kot Offensive]] in June 2010, which resulted in heavy insurgent casualties.{{cite press release|url=http://www.defence.gov.au/media/departmentaltpl.cfm?CurrentId=10190|archiveurl=http://webarchive.nla.gov.au/gov/20150624193254/http://www.defence.gov.au/media/departmentaltpl.cfm?CurrentId=10190|title=Anzac Day in Gizab|publisher=Department of Defence|date=24 April 2010|accessdate=16 June 2010|archivedate=25 June 2015}}{{cite press release|url=http://www.defence.gov.au/defencenews/articles/0616.htm|title=Insurgents driven out of Shah Wali Kot|publisher=Department of Defence|date=16 June 2010|accessdate=16 June 2010}} The bulk of SOTG was withdrawn from Afghanistan in late 2013 as part of a drawdown of Australian forces, although some special forces remained after this date as part of the small Australian force maintained in the country.{{sfn|McPhedran|2013|p=1}} The Regiment lost 12 personnel killed while deployed to Afghanistan, along with one killed during a pre-deployment exercise.{{cite web|url=http://2commando.gov.au/honour-roll/2-commando-honour-roll|title=Honour Roll|date=2013|website=2nd Commando Regiment|publisher=Department of Defence|accessdate=10 September 2014}}{{Cite web|title=Battle casualties in Afghanistan|url=http://www.defence.gov.au/operations/afghanistan/personnel.asp|work=Global Operations: Afghanistan|publisher=Department of Defence|accessdate=10 September 2014}} The Regiment served in 20 SOTG rotations in Afghanistan, with deployments ranging from about four to six, seven, and eight months.{{cite web|title=Operation Slipper – Where did people deploy from?|url=http://www.army.gov.au/Our-history/History-in-Focus/Operation-Slipper/Deployed-personnel-by-location|website=Australian Army|accessdate=25 May 2016}}{{cite web|title=The Last Commando Part One – Transcript|url=http://www.abc.net.au/austory/content/2014/s4019466.htm|website=Australian Story|publisher=Australian Broadcasting Corporation|date=5 June 2014|accessdate=2 July 2016}} For its actions, the Regiment was collectively awarded the [[Unit Citation for Gallantry]] and the [[Meritorious Unit Citation]]. On 26 March 2013, it was announced that Special Operations Command would receive the first [[battle honour]] awarded to an Australian Army unit for actions since the end of the Vietnam War for its performance during the Shah Wali Kot Offensive in Afghanistan from May to June 2010. The battle honour, titled "Eastern Shah Wali Kot", was awarded in recognition of the operational actions of the SASR and 2nd Commando Regiment from Australian Special Operations Task Group Rotation XII.{{cite press release|title=Special Operations Units Awarded Battle Honour|publisher=Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet|date=26 March 2013|url=http://www.pm.gov.au/press-office/special-operations-units-awarded-battle-honour|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130413043551/http://www.pm.gov.au/press-office/special-operations-units-awarded-battle-honour|archivedate=13 April 2013|accessdate=26 March 2013}} A number of the regiment's personnel have also received individual decorations for their actions in Afghanistan. A posthumous [[Victoria Cross for Australia]] was awarded to [[Cameron Baird]] for actions in Uruzgan Province in June 2013.{{sfn|Swan|2014|}} In addition, as of October 2010 six [[Distinguished Service Cross (Australia)|Distinguished Service Crosses]], eleven [[Distinguished Service Medal (Australia)|Distinguished Service Medals]], seven [[Medal for Gallantry|Medals for Gallantry]] and three [[Star of Gallantry|Stars of Gallantry]] had been awarded to 2nd Commando Regiment personnel for service in Afghanistan.{{sfn|Dodd|2010|}} ===Military intervention against ISIL=== In September 2014, as part of [[Operation Okra]] the Australian Army deployed a Special Operations Task Group (SOTG) of approximately 200 personnel to the United Arab Emirates in preparation for operations to assist and advise Iraqi Security Forces following an offensive by [[Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant|Islamic State]] forces.{{cite news |url=http://www.defence.gov.au/news/armynews/editions/1338/1338.pdf|title=Support to Iraq|newspaper=Army: The Soldiers' Newspaper |edition=1338|date=9 October 2014|publisher=Department of Defence|location=Canberra|page=3|issn=0729-5685}} The soldiers were expected to be deployed to Iraq when a legal framework covering their presence in the country was agreed between the Australian and Iraqi Governments.{{sfn|Brissenden|2014a|}} The majority of the SOTG was reported to be made up of C Company, 2nd Commando Regiment.{{sfn|Brissenden|2014b|}} It began moving into Iraq in early November.{{sfn|Griffiths|2014|}} The 2nd Commando Regiment was tasked with training the Iraq government's Counter Terrorism Service.{{sfn|Williams|2015|}} Personnel from SOTG have also been involved in co-ordinating airstrikes remotely to assist Iraqi forces engaged in clearance operations.{{sfn|Wroe|2015|}} From September 2015, the strength of SOTG rotations were reduced to approximately 80 personnel.{{cite web|url=http://news.defence.gov.au/2015/10/07/press-conference-with-vice-admiral-david-johnston-update-on-australian-defence-force-operations-2/|work=Transcript|title=Press conference with Vice Admiral David Johnston – Update on Australian Defence Force operations|publisher=Department of Defence|date=7 October 2015|accessdate=29 November 2015}}{{cite media release|author=Prime Minister and Minister for Defence|title=Training Iraqi law enforcement agencies|url=http://www.minister.defence.gov.au/2016/07/20/prime-minister-minister-for-defence-joint-media-release-training-iraqi-law-enforcement-agencies/|accessdate=31 July 2016|date=20 July 2016}} ==Current organisation== The regiment consists of a headquarters, four commando companies, a logistics support company, an operational support company and a signals squadron. It is believed to currently be organised as follows:{{sfn|Horner|2008|p=329}}{{sfn|Brissenden|2014b|}} * Regimental Headquarters ** A Company ** B Company ** C Company ** D Company ** 126 Signal Squadron{{cite web|url=http://2commando.gov.au/careers/employment-roles/commando/signaller|title=Commando Signallers (126 Signals Squadron)|date=2013|website=2nd Commando Regiment|publisher=Department of Defence|accessdate=11 November 2014}} ** Operations Support Company ** Logistics Support Company ''Incorporates the role of Tactical Assault Group (East) (on rotation).'' ==Uniform and equipment== Following the renaming of the unit a new badge was chosen to reflect the history and traditions of the [[Australian commandos|Independent Companies]] that served during the Second World War by including the distinctive "double diamond" [[Unit Colour Patch|unit colour patch]] shape in the regimental badge along with the traditional [[Fairbairn-Sykes Fighting Knife|commando knife]]. The unit's motto is ''Foras Admonitio'', which is Latin for "Without Warning". Qualified commandos are awarded the Sherwood green commando [[beret]].{{sfn|Dodd|2010|}} Distinctive commando [[Parachutist Badge (United Kingdom)#Special Forces|parachute wings]] are worn, depicting a parachute backed by a pair of black drooping wings on a green background.{{sfn|Jobson|2009|p=186}} The Australian Army Stiletto dagger is also worn on ceremonial occasions.{{cite news |url=http://www.defence.gov.au/news/armynews/editions/1335/1335.pdf|title=Dagger makes a comeback|newspaper=Army: The Soldiers' Newspaper |edition=1335|date=28 August 2014|publisher=Department of Defence|location=Canberra|page=8|issn=0729-5685}} A garter blue [[lanyard]] is worn.{{sfn|Terrett|Taubert|2015|p=117}} A variety of weapons systems are used, including the [[M4 carbine|M4A5 carbine]], [[HK417]], and [[SR-25]] rifles.{{sfn|Neville|2016|p=68}} Sidearms include the [[USP Tactical]] and [[Browning Hi-Power|L9A1 Browning High Power]].{{sfn|Neville|2016|p=32}} The Heckler and Koch [[Heckler & Koch MP5 |MP5 submachine gun]] is used in the counter-terrorist role.{{cite web |url= http://www.army.gov.au/Our-work/Equipment-and-clothing/Small-Arms/MP5 |title= MP5 9 millimetre |publisher=Australian Army |accessdate=28 September 2016}}{{sfn|Neville|2016|p=63 and 74}} Sniper rifles include the [[Barrett M82|Barrett M82A1]], [[AW50F]] and [[Blaser R93 Tactical |Blaser Tactical 2]].{{sfn|Neville|2016|p=200}} Support weapons include both the Mk48 Maximi Modular and [[FN Minimi|Para Minimi]],{{sfn|Neville|2016|pp=204–222}} as well as the [[FN MAG|MAG 58]].{{sfn|Neville|2016|pp=204–223}} Direct and indirect fire support weapons used include 66 mm [[M72 LAW|M72 rocket]]s, 84 mm [[Carl Gustav recoilless rifle#M3 MAAWS|M3 MAAWS]], [[FGM-148 Javelin]]s, [[M2 Browning|M2-QCB Browning]] .50 calibre machine guns, [[Mk 19 grenade launcher]]s, and 81 mm [[mortar (weapon)|mortar]]s.{{sfn|Neville|2015|p=}}{{sfn|Neville|2016|pp=223–240}}{{cite web|url= http://2commando.gov.au/careers/employment-roles/commando/mortarman|title= Commando: Mortarman|date=2013|website=2nd Commando Regiment|publisher=Department of Defence|accessdate=28 September 2016}}{{refn|The Mk 19 grenade launcher is currently being replaced by the [[Mk 47 Striker|Mk 47 Light-Weight Automatic Grenade Launcher]].{{sfn|Foster|2016|p=5}}|group=Note}} Vehicles include the new Special Operations Vehicle – Commando (SOV-Cdo), based on Supacat's [[SC_Group#High_Mobility_Transporter|HMT Extenda]], 89 of which are currently being acquired.{{cite journal|url= http://www.defence.gov.au/dmo/NewsMedia/DMOBulletin/Contract-signed-for-Special-Operations-Vehicles|title= Contract signed for Special Operations Vehicles|work= CASG Bulletin |issue=June 2016|publisher=Department of Defence|accessdate=27 September 2016}} ==Selection and training== [[File:2nd Commando Regiment soldiers jump from MC-130.JPG|thumb|Commandos jump into Shoalwater Bay from a [[United States Air Force|U.S. Air Force]] [[Lockheed MC-130|MC-130]] transport during Exercise Talisman Saber 2011]] Any member of the Australian Defence Force may apply for entry into the 2nd Commando Regiment.{{cite web|url=http://2commando.gov.au/careers/how-to-apply|title=How to Apply|date=2013|website=2nd Commando Regiment|publisher=Department of Defence|accessdate=11 November 2014}} Applicants may also be accepted via the Special Forces Direct Recruitment Scheme (DRS), where selected and screened civilians undertake an accelerated 80-day infantry training program prior to commencing the Special Forces selection process.{{cite web|title=Commando: Entry|url=http://www.defencejobs.gov.au/army/jobs/Commando/Entry/|website=Defence Jobs|date=2014|publisher=Defence Force Recruiting|accessdate=10 Nov 2014}} If a candidate fails any part of the selection course they will be returned to their unit, or transferred to one of the infantry battalions of the [[Royal Australian Regiment]] if they are a DRS candidate. Candidates must complete the Special Forces Screen Test and if successful move onto the six-week Commando Selection and Training Course (CSTC) conducted at the Special Forces Training Centre (SFTC), in [[Singleton, New South Wales]]. Further training then is undertaken during Commando Initial Employment Training, also known as the "Reinforcement Cycle". Upon successful completion of all courses soldiers are posted into one of the Commando Companies where further specialist training occurs.{{cite web|title=Commando: Employment Training|url=http://www.defencejobs.gov.au/army/jobs/Commando/EmploymentTraining/|website=Defence Jobs|date=2014|publisher=Defence Force Recruiting|accessdate=10 November 2014}}{{cite web|url=http://2commando.gov.au/careers/selection-and-training-course|title=Selection and Training Course|date=2013|website=2nd Commando Regiment|publisher=Department of Defence|accessdate=11 November 2014}}{{cite web|url=http://2commando.gov.au/careers/reinforcement-training|title=Reinforcement Training|date=2013|website=2nd Commando Regiment|publisher=Department of Defence|accessdate=11 November 2014}}{{cite web|url=http://2commando.gov.au/careers/specialist-training|title=Specialist Training Training|date=2013|website=2nd Commando Regiment|publisher=Department of Defence|accessdate=11 November 2014}} ==Notes== ;Footnotes {{Reflist|group=Note}} ;Citations {{reflist|4}} ==References== {{refbegin}} *{{cite news |url=http://www.theage.com.au/news/National/Aussie-troops-kill-150-Taliban-fighters/2006/09/12/1157826945083.html |title=Aussie troops kill 150 Taliban fighters |date=12 September 2006 |newspaper=[[The Age]] |publisher=Fairfax Media |location=Melbourne, Victoria |issn=0312-6307 |ref=CITEREFThe_Age2010}} *{{cite web |url=http://www.defence.gov.au/publications/lessons.pdf |title=The War in Iraq.
